title: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 14: Ambion Trizol RNA Extraction in Microcentrifuge Tubes with Turbo DNAfree Digestion
title_html: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 14: Ambion Trizol RNA Extraction in Microcentrifuge Tubes with Turbo DNAfree Digestion

source.description: Clean all surfaces and equipment with 20 % bleach, 95 % ethanol, and RNase Zap, and place supplies in hood.
Prepare sample tubes with labels.
Fill microcentrifuge tubes with 5 zirconia beads (if they have not been done before tissue collection).
Prepare aliquots of the following solutions into 50mL Falcon tubes: 75 % ethanol, 100 % chloroform, 100 % isopropanol.
Fill dewar with liquid N2.

Get samples from
and place them in the black shaker block that is sitting in a bath of liquid N2 (if already in microcentrifuge tubes), and check labels.
Prepare frozen tissue in microcentrifuge tubes from 50 ml Falcons (if tissue is not in them already).
Before pulverizing the frozen tissue, check each tube for beads, making sure they are easily moving within the tube.
Taking the black shaker block with the 24 samples, place tightly into the automatic shaker, doing this quickly as to not allow thawing.

Place block back into the liquid nitrogen cooler if needed to shake another
.

Add
of TRIzol solution.

source.body:
Before opening the tubes, tapping the tube on the bottom on the bench will empty most of the leaf tissue that is in the lid from the shaking process.
If it does not move, you can use the vortexer with the solution added to force it out of the lid.
Optional adjustment is to add to of 20 % Sarkosyl to each sample with the TRIzol.

source.description:
After each tube has had the TRIzol solution added, vortex immediately, both the top and bottom of the tube, until all tissue is hydrated. Vortexing for
can be common.
Then place tube on ice, and do this sequentially until you have all 24 tubes finished.

source.body: If Sarkosyl is used, be aware it will be a thick, viscous layer at the interface. Try not to pull any into the aqueous layer.

Using pipette, pull off excess ethanol collected at the bottom of the tube.

source.body: Final pellet should be clear. If white, then may still have salts and you can repeat the ethanol wash a second time, however, the DNA removal step seems to also remove salt contamination.

source.body: If the RNA is pure, it should be instant.

source.description: Check on nanodrop for concentration.

source.body: Samples should be diluted to be less than before proceeding to the DNAase steps. However, we have done the following steps with samples that are up to and had success. We suggest only diluting when you have or of RNA.

source.body: is ideal, but there will most likely be more. Expect some loss from theTurbo Kit. Also, if the first time the spectra appeared contaminated, this step may have cleaned it some. The OD 260/280 ratio should be 1.8 to 2.2 (not less than 1.6), in order to get good transcriptome library construction.

source.description: Fill two small coolers with liquid nitrogen (one for microcentrifuge tubes, the other for Falcon tubes).

Doing about 3 or 4 plants at a time, use forceps or a spatula to move
to
of tissue into the microcentrifuge tubes from the 50 ml Falcon tubes.
Get a weight for each of the samples, add more if necessary.

source.body: If you are doing aquatic plants use 2x the weight since so much of the weight is water.

source.description: Repeat these steps until you have finished all of the samples.

Keep on liquid nitrogen, until TRIzol is added.

source.body: Do not change this volume or more protein will be forced into the aqueous layer.

If you suspect the sample does not look “clean” or if you had used the Sarkosyl addition, repeat steps 16.1 to 16.5 (i.e. the chloroform step).
Mix by inverting the rack.
Vortex until the pellet is loose.

To aid in dissolution, incubate at
for
in water bath.

source.body: Never incubate longer than at this temperature. Also never increase the temperature, as this can cause RNA degradation. If pellet does not dissolve immediately, store at overnight (or until dissolved). However, the best samples dissolve with no trouble.

source.description: Vortex gently when finished.
Transfer to a new tube.

description:
Implemented by: Ingrid Jordon-Thaden and Nicholas Miles (Soltis Labs)
This procedure eliminates the mortar and pestle homogenization of tissues and instead grinds tissue in 2 ml microcentrifuge tubes. The method closely follows Ambion’s protocols and could be used in a 96-well format. This method worked great for species that proved to be difficult to extract with other methods (i.e. woody and aquatic plants).
This protocol is part of a collection of eighteen protocols used to isolate total RNA from plant tissue. (RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Collection: https://www.protocols.io/view/rna-isolation-from-plant-tissue-439gyr6)
